description: Windows Hello for Business was introduced with the Windows 10 Creators Update. WHfB allows businesses to implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) as part of the Windows client logon process. This series introduces the viewers Windows Hello for Business and then walks you through the entire process of deploying WHfB in a business environment.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike introduce the viewers to Windows Hello for Business. They discuss the risks associated with standard password usage and explore how Windows Hello for Business can provide a more secure authentication experience.
episodes.title: Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.017
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.017 --> 00:00:08.554
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.554 --> 00:00:10.783
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.783 --> 00:00:15.380
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

5
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:17.570
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:17.570 --> 00:00:19.650
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:19.650 --> 00:00:22.360
Here today with a very special
series that we're kicking off,

8
00:00:22.360 --> 00:00:24.550
which is Windows Hello for Business.

9
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:27.210
And I've got a special guest
here in the studio with us, Mr.

10
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:30.100
Mike Stephens, who's gonna be helping
us kinda walk through Windows Hello for

11
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:32.240
Business and see what it can do for us.

12
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:34.080
Mike, thanks for
joining us in the studios.

13
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:36.450
>> Thanks for having me Don,
it's a pleasure to be here.

14
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:40.920
>> And what's on our agenda for
today as far as where to get started?

15
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:45.090
>> Yeah, so, Windows Hello for Business
is a new thing that we brought out.

16
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:49.410
And this is going to,
basically it's a password replacement.

17
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:51.780
We're targeting users on passwords.

18
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:55.020
And so what we're gonna do today
is talk about the concepts

19
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:56.840
of leading up to Windows Hello.

20
00:00:56.840 --> 00:01:00.845
And why we need Windows Hello
in the infrastructure today?

21
00:01:00.845 --> 00:01:04.650
And the first thing here is to talk
about password itself because you have

22
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:05.580
a problem.

23
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:07.830
And when you have a problem,
you need to solve that problem.

24
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.290
So our first thing today is talk
about that passwords are bad.

25
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:13.140
We've been using passwords for
20 something years.

26
00:01:13.140 --> 00:01:14.650
And there's just the go to.

27
00:01:14.650 --> 00:01:18.410
They're reliable on the sense that
most of use have figured out how to

28
00:01:18.410 --> 00:01:21.080
create a password that's
semi-strong enough.

29
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:23.960
And we just have hard time
getting off of them because so

30
00:01:23.960 --> 00:01:27.080
much of the infrastructure
depends on the password.

31
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:31.510
And so today what we need to do is
look at why is the password so bad and

32
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:33.040
why do we need to get off of that?

33
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:36.570
And so what we really need to do
is break down what a password is.

34
00:01:36.570 --> 00:01:40.350
And at the end of the day,
a password is just a symmetric key.

35
00:01:40.350 --> 00:01:43.773
We type in a password that we know,
so it's like my favorite dog or

36
00:01:43.773 --> 00:01:45.690
something to that effect.

37
00:01:45.690 --> 00:01:50.680
But underneath the covers that password
is hashed with a hashing algorithm or

38
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:52.880
we use a key derivation like PBKDF2 and

39
00:01:52.880 --> 00:01:57.280
we throw some salt in there, and
maybe some additional entropy.

40
00:01:57.280 --> 00:02:00.140
And the output of that
is basically it's a key.

41
00:02:00.140 --> 00:02:02.820
It's a symmetric key,
it's the secret that I know and

42
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:05.859
that it's the secret that
the authenticating server knows.

43
00:02:05.859 --> 00:02:09.830
And so that's server is just going to
compare that key to the key I typed

44
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:15.040
in after doing all this computational
stuff and that's how we authenticate.

45
00:02:15.040 --> 00:02:17.780
>> Well, I know you said we've
been using passwords for 20 years,

46
00:02:17.780 --> 00:02:19.860
probably longer for certain things.

47
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:24.780
You watch the old war spy movies where
they had the password response type thing.

48
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:26.650
That technology's been around a long time.

49
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:28.700
It's far more advanced
now than it used to be.

50
00:02:28.700 --> 00:02:30.650
You mentioned hashes and
salts and all that.

51
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:34.430
So, if we have a highly
secured password like that,

52
00:02:34.430 --> 00:02:37.740
why isn't that a good technology for
authentication?

53
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:41.840
>> So, it's not a good technology for
authentication because there are three

54
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:45.280
components that we've looked at when
we did Windows Hello for Business.

55
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:47.850
And one is passwords are phishable.

56
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:51.620
You can trick somebody into
giving you your password.

57
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:54.000
The other thing is
passwords are replayable.

58
00:02:54.000 --> 00:02:56.780
The great things about
passwords is thy are portable,

59
00:02:56.780 --> 00:02:58.685
he bad thing is that they are portable.

60
00:02:58.685 --> 00:03:01.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> Once I get one, I can use it anywhere,

61
00:03:01.390 --> 00:03:04.350
and so if I happen to know
Don's password I can go back

62
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:07.180
to Washington in my office and
I can pretend to be Don.

63
00:03:07.180 --> 00:03:08.510
And it works.

64
00:03:08.510 --> 00:03:12.000
>> At that point the computer has no
way of knowing whether it's you or

65
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:13.990
me because all it's checking for
is a password.

66
00:03:13.990 --> 00:03:16.310
If you've got my password,
it thinks you're me.

67
00:03:16.310 --> 00:03:17.760
>> Right, it's a single factor.

68
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:23.160
It's just, I just know that you typed in a
user identity and you typed in a password,

69
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:26.980
and on the back-end server that's doing
the authentication that password worked.

70
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:29.810
And so it has no other choice but
to let that user in.

71
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:31.390
The other thing that it is,

72
00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:35.920
is that we talked about that there
are phishable and what the big thing and

73
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:39.540
what we've seen in a lot of the TV
today is they're breachable.

74
00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:42.040
Like I said,
in that talk about the password.

75
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:46.280
When I create a password and we do all
that crypto underneath, that password

76
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:51.130
still has to be stored on the back end so
it knows how to authenticate me.

77
00:03:51.130 --> 00:03:53.690
And so that's become a very big target.

78
00:03:53.690 --> 00:03:57.270
We've had quite a few things that
we've heard in the news about people

79
00:03:57.270 --> 00:03:59.900
having identity theft because
these breaches on these servers.

80
00:03:59.900 --> 00:04:03.790
So the idea of Windows Hello
is to go to not one factor or

81
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:08.120
single factor but two factors of
authentication and we'll get into that.

82
00:04:08.120 --> 00:04:11.530
But the point is that two
factors of authentication and

83
00:04:11.530 --> 00:04:15.391
design it in the way to where we can
try to move forward to, non-phishable,

84
00:04:15.391 --> 00:04:19.100
non-replayable and non-breachable.

85
00:04:19.100 --> 00:04:23.590
So with that I want to go into, this is
where we have this whole password thing

86
00:04:23.590 --> 00:04:26.420
and so why I wanted to just
give the users or viewers,

87
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:31.030
I should say, give the viewers a view of
how passwords are easily breached today.

88
00:04:31.030 --> 00:04:34.320
I have this little PowerPoint animation
here that we can show you here.

89
00:04:34.320 --> 00:04:37.640
And my head's covering up the bottom
there, but we'll get to that.

90
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:40.060
So here we have this is,

91
00:04:40.060 --> 00:04:44.000
humans are humans, and
we don't like to use complex passwords.

92
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:47.210
And the problem is,
we end up using the same password over and

93
00:04:47.210 --> 00:04:50.210
over again, because, well, we remember it.

94
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:54.220
So the problem here is,
I use the password at Bank.com.

95
00:04:54.220 --> 00:04:57.280
I'll also use that same password all
the way through my social media,

96
00:04:57.280 --> 00:04:58.400
maybe some other things, but

97
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:03.050
then I go to this one obscure sight that
I only need to do one or two things.

98
00:05:03.050 --> 00:05:07.250
But, like a lot of sights, they make me
want to actually sign in with something.

99
00:05:07.250 --> 00:05:10.370
And so, I use the same password,
cuz it's easy to remember.

100
00:05:10.370 --> 00:05:14.880
Well, while we think of our bank being
a very secure and very trustworthy entity.

101
00:05:14.880 --> 00:05:19.380
As we go down this list here on the right
side, we start getting our level of trust

102
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:23.170
starts to diminish until we
go to Obscure.com, which,

103
00:05:23.170 --> 00:05:26.610
I don't know what they are but there was
something on the website I wanted to see.

104
00:05:26.610 --> 00:05:28.140
And so what happens is,

105
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:31.970
now the attacker, he's just gonna find
the weakest link in all of these.

106
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:36.280
He's not gonna go directly to the bank
because banks they are tasked with

107
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:38.320
making sure that people don't breach.

108
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:42.847
So what we wanna do then is that
basically the attacker finds Obscure.com,

109
00:05:42.847 --> 00:05:44.550
hacks that password.

110
00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:47.720
And now all of a sudden,
as we alluded to in the intro here,

111
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:51.372
that attacker can be me anywhere,
all over the place.

112
00:05:51.372 --> 00:05:53.770
Bank.com, Social.com.

113
00:05:53.770 --> 00:05:58.997
And so now, what ends up happening is that
I'm actually compromised at that point and

114
00:05:58.997 --> 00:06:01.465
my identity is gone on multiple sites and

115
00:06:01.465 --> 00:06:04.900
then you just have this
runaway identity problem here.

116
00:06:04.900 --> 00:06:07.820
>> And there's been some high
visibility instances of this lately.

117
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:11.000
I know Apple was subjected to this
where they were saying there were

118
00:06:11.000 --> 00:06:12.600
hundreds of thousands of
accounts were breached and

119
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:16.020
it turned out that they themselves
weren't breached, it was other sites and

120
00:06:16.020 --> 00:06:19.660
through password reuse they were able
to compromise those credentials.

121
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:22.610
So that's a real problem not just for
one company but for

122
00:06:22.610 --> 00:06:24.670
every company,
every organization that is out there.

123
00:06:24.670 --> 00:06:27.650
>> That's a great point, Don, yeah,
I mean the problem we have today

124
00:06:27.650 --> 00:06:32.200
is that we are really,
heavily dependent on passwords today.

125
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:34.960
And it's a big mountain to move, we've

126
00:06:34.960 --> 00:06:40.110
done several years of investigation on how
can we get to a world without passwords?

127
00:06:40.110 --> 00:06:44.620
And it's not an easy task, it's going
to take a lot of investigation in

128
00:06:44.620 --> 00:06:47.850
each particular enterprise to figure
out how they can move their business

129
00:06:47.850 --> 00:06:50.690
from something that we call weak
credential, which is just user name and

130
00:06:50.690 --> 00:06:55.280
password to a strong credential,
that is, Windows Hello for Business.

131
00:06:55.280 --> 00:07:00.570
So what I wanna do and how is Windows
Hello for Business a strong credential?

132
00:07:00.570 --> 00:07:04.655
Well, let's start with what's
two factor authentication, or

133
00:07:04.655 --> 00:07:07.495
basically multi-factor authentication.

134
00:07:07.495 --> 00:07:09.606
And there's a great document,

135
00:07:09.606 --> 00:07:15.485
NIST SP800-171 has a definition of
what multi-factor authentication is.

136
00:07:15.485 --> 00:07:17.125
But we can simplify it here.

137
00:07:17.125 --> 00:07:19.755
Basically, it's something you have.

138
00:07:19.755 --> 00:07:24.765
It's typically a private key, and
highly recommended that it not be movable,

139
00:07:24.765 --> 00:07:27.855
or secured by some sort
of security device.

140
00:07:27.855 --> 00:07:33.070
A common thing is a smart card, or
perhaps a TPM inside the computer.

141
00:07:33.070 --> 00:07:37.600
The next thing that we have is something
you know and this can be a pin.

142
00:07:37.600 --> 00:07:40.790
And these pins they kind of,
people get, well, pin and password,

143
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:43.110
that's kind of confusing,
isn't it the same?

144
00:07:43.110 --> 00:07:46.200
And its really not because in these
scenarios where you're doing multifactor

145
00:07:46.200 --> 00:07:50.280
authentication, the pin is actually
entropy, it's not really stored anywhere.

146
00:07:50.280 --> 00:07:55.200
It's basing on the fact that the user
is going to provide this entropy that

147
00:07:55.200 --> 00:07:57.440
has been given during
a time of provisioning.

148
00:07:57.440 --> 00:08:00.744
And it will use that entropy to do
some sort of computation that will

149
00:08:00.744 --> 00:08:04.524
eventually then say, yes,
that is the user, because they knew this.

150
00:08:04.524 --> 00:08:08.430
It doesn't have to compare
The PIN to a stored PIN.

151
00:08:08.430 --> 00:08:09.008
And then,

152
00:08:09.008 --> 00:08:13.540
the final thing that we have here is that
it's something that is a part of you.

153
00:08:13.540 --> 00:08:17.270
In this case, Windows Hello, we have
ability to where we can tie Windows Hello

154
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:18.800
for Business to use biometrics.

155
00:08:18.800 --> 00:08:22.145
So then you could sign in with your face,
or you can do fingerprint reader.

156
00:08:22.145 --> 00:08:26.835
So it's a very fluid and easy motion,
and it's kind of very futuristic for us,

157
00:08:26.835 --> 00:08:29.965
because you get to go and show all your
relatives how you just sign into your

158
00:08:29.965 --> 00:08:32.555
computer using your face,
or using a fingerprint.

159
00:08:32.555 --> 00:08:34.355
And it's very, very cool.

160
00:08:34.355 --> 00:08:37.845
So, the objective, and
when we did Windows Hello for Business,

161
00:08:37.845 --> 00:08:42.851
was to basically work on those
three pillars of non-fishable,

162
00:08:42.851 --> 00:08:46.790
non-replayable, and
basically non-breachable.

163
00:08:46.790 --> 00:08:50.030
And the way we do that is we start
with the something you have.

164
00:08:50.030 --> 00:08:50.810
Windows Hello for

165
00:08:50.810 --> 00:08:56.160
Business is essentially going to create
a private key in the computer's TPM.

166
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:59.420
So we support TPM 1.2 and 2.0.

167
00:08:59.420 --> 00:09:03.825
And for older machines we do
support a fallback to software.

168
00:09:03.825 --> 00:09:07.540
Although for enterprises we have group
policies that will actually allow them to

169
00:09:07.540 --> 00:09:10.650
force a hardware one where you
won't fall back to software.

170
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:13.250
But we have to keep in
mind that everybody's

171
00:09:13.250 --> 00:09:16.130
computer refresh cycle is
not what it's going to be.

172
00:09:16.130 --> 00:09:19.595
>> And I think at this point pretty much
every computer made in the last three to

173
00:09:19.595 --> 00:09:21.198
five years should have a TPM in it.

174
00:09:21.198 --> 00:09:24.551
It's kind of becoming more of a rarity to
find a computer that doesn't have a TPM

175
00:09:24.551 --> 00:09:25.990
integrated, right?

176
00:09:25.990 --> 00:09:29.736
>> Yeah, it just depends on
where you procure your hardware.

177
00:09:29.736 --> 00:09:33.710
TPMs, when you do a build of materials for
these laptops and everything,

178
00:09:33.710 --> 00:09:35.690
these manufacturers are cutting costs.

179
00:09:35.690 --> 00:09:40.090
A TPM might be $0.17, but
that's $0.17 to the bottom line.

180
00:09:40.090 --> 00:09:44.400
So you definitely want to make sure that
when you are looking at Windows Hello for

181
00:09:44.400 --> 00:09:48.370
Business and upgrading your hardware
that you make sure that you call out to

182
00:09:48.370 --> 00:09:53.130
that vendor that you want a TPM,
and preferably you want a TPM 2.0.

183
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:57.660
I know that Microsoft has recently changed
their hardware guidelines where TPM 2.0

184
00:09:57.660 --> 00:10:02.530
is what we are recommending for
Windows Logo PCs right now.

185
00:10:02.530 --> 00:10:06.060
And TPM 2.0 is just
a better version all out.

186
00:10:06.060 --> 00:10:11.120
It doesn't lock out as easy, it has better
performances, it supports more crypto.

187
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:13.160
So, it's just a better overall thing.

188
00:10:13.160 --> 00:10:15.870
But we know that it's gonna
be a gradual movement

189
00:10:15.870 --> 00:10:18.220
before you get from TPM 1.2 to 2.0.

190
00:10:18.220 --> 00:10:22.980
But most PCs in an enterprise
will have a TPM 1.2.

191
00:10:22.980 --> 00:10:24.380
There's already things that use it.

192
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:29.170
Like right now BitLocker needs a TPM 1
to use that, and there are other things

193
00:10:29.170 --> 00:10:33.410
that is more and more prevalent where
TPMs are just being used more and more.

194
00:10:33.410 --> 00:10:37.550
So that's not really a hard thing, but we
need to have that TPM because what do we

195
00:10:37.550 --> 00:10:41.910
want, we wanna have that thing that you
know, or sorry, that thing that you have

196
00:10:41.910 --> 00:10:45.015
is gonna be a private key,
that private key is generated in a TPM.

197
00:10:45.015 --> 00:10:48.570
TPMs have all this crypto built into them,

198
00:10:48.570 --> 00:10:52.700
so they can do random number generator,
they do all this stuff inside the TMP.

199
00:10:52.700 --> 00:10:54.930
And they generate a key.

200
00:10:54.930 --> 00:10:57.950
And that key is then
wrapped with a key that's

201
00:10:57.950 --> 00:11:01.210
burnt into the TPM at
the time of manufacturing.

202
00:11:01.210 --> 00:11:05.310
And that key is different for
each TPM that's manufactured.

203
00:11:05.310 --> 00:11:07.760
And so
TPMs don't really have a lot of storage.

204
00:11:07.760 --> 00:11:11.760
So what happens is is that key
is wrapped with that unique key

205
00:11:11.760 --> 00:11:16.450
that's burnt into the TPM at the time of
manufacturing and then persisted to disk.

206
00:11:16.450 --> 00:11:20.540
And so that way, even if you were to get
that key and move it laterally one way or

207
00:11:20.540 --> 00:11:24.620
another, it's not gonna work because
you need to feed it into the TPM that

208
00:11:24.620 --> 00:11:25.540
actually created it.

209
00:11:25.540 --> 00:11:29.490
And so that's where we can get this
where we don't have lateral movement of

210
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:32.120
the actual something you have.

211
00:11:32.120 --> 00:11:36.310
The next thing that we're gonna
talk about is is that the something

212
00:11:36.310 --> 00:11:37.480
you know which is the PIN.

213
00:11:37.480 --> 00:11:42.120
As I mentioned, that's entropy, and
so we don't persist the PIN anywhere.

214
00:11:42.120 --> 00:11:47.350
And so that way, if that PIN is ever
entered wrong, then it's not gonna work.

215
00:11:47.350 --> 00:11:50.070
Because what happens is is the way to

well, that if you try to have a conflict
between Windows Hello for Business and

437
00:23:59.400 --> 00:24:02.415
the convenient sign in we kinda just
don't let you create a pin at all.

438
00:24:02.415 --> 00:24:05.483
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, and for
a business we don't want that anyway, so

439
00:24:05.483 --> 00:24:08.315
it makes sense that we'd stick
with the Windows Hello for

440
00:24:08.315 --> 00:24:11.460
Business infrastructure and
get that implemented properly.

441
00:24:11.460 --> 00:24:14.330
>> Absolutely, it's the stronger of
the versions that we want people to use.

442
00:24:14.330 --> 00:24:17.770
Like I said, even with your Microsoft
account it's a good idea to

443
00:24:17.770 --> 00:24:19.630
just go ahead and create that pin.

444
00:24:19.630 --> 00:24:23.060
And if you can get hardware,
there's a lot of cameras,

445
00:24:23.060 --> 00:24:24.430
third party cameras that are coming out.

446
00:24:24.430 --> 00:24:28.470
There's more, a lot of fingerprint readers
I'm seeing in laptops now more than ever.

447
00:24:28.470 --> 00:24:33.780
So, it's really starting to get
a popularity and gaining in momentum.

448
00:24:33.780 --> 00:24:36.760
So if any time you can do those things is,

449
00:24:36.760 --> 00:24:41.250
moving off of a password is just
the be all end all of what we want.

450
00:24:41.250 --> 00:24:43.480
>> All right, well Mike, I think
that's probably a pretty good spot for

451
00:24:43.480 --> 00:24:44.320
us to wrap this one up.

452
00:24:44.320 --> 00:24:46.550
Did you have anything else you
wanted to mention before we close?

453
00:24:46.550 --> 00:24:49.140
>> No, we're good,
we're gonna have a lot more to talk about,

454
00:24:49.140 --> 00:24:52.210
and we're gonna be here for
a while talking about Windows Hello, and

455
00:24:52.210 --> 00:24:54.600
setting it up, and
making sure people can use it.

456
00:24:54.600 --> 00:24:56.210
>> All right everybody,
well, in this episode,

457
00:24:56.210 --> 00:24:58.750
we had a chance to learn a little bit
about Windows Hello for Business.

458
00:24:58.750 --> 00:25:01.660
We talked a bit about the reason
why we want to have it, and

459
00:25:01.660 --> 00:25:05.738
why passwords are no longer cutting
the mustard for our security solutions.

460
00:25:05.738 --> 00:25:08.740
And we talk a little bit about the
infrastructure that we're going to need

461
00:25:08.740 --> 00:25:11.060
to put Windows Hello for
Business in place.

462
00:25:11.060 --> 00:25:14.000
And in the coming up episodes
we're gonna be seeing actually how

463
00:25:14.000 --> 00:25:17.510
to put that into place, get it implemented
in your on premises environment.

464
00:25:17.510 --> 00:25:19.140
I hope you enjoyed it,
be sure to stay tuned for

465
00:25:19.140 --> 00:25:22.240
the follow up episodes cuz we're really
gonna get to the good stuff coming up.

466
00:25:22.240 --> 00:25:25.810
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

467
00:25:25.810 --> 00:25:26.830
>> And I'm Mike Stephens.

468
00:25:26.830 --> 00:25:28.247
>> And we'll see you next time.

469
00:25:28.247 --> 00:25:34.284

470
00:25:34.284 --> 00:25:37.279
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss the necessary steps for an organization planning to deploy Windows Hello for Business. The discuss how to select between a hybrid or on-premises deployment. They also discuss how to select an appropriate trust model for your deployment. At the end of the episode, Mike describes the high-level steps for building a deployment strategy.
episodes.title: Planning the Deployment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.874
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.874 --> 00:00:06.505
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.505 --> 00:00:08.352
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.352 --> 00:00:12.355
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.355 --> 00:00:15.300
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

6
00:00:15.300 --> 00:00:17.400
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.400 --> 00:00:21.492
I'm your host, Don Pezet back again with
another episode of Windows Hello for

8
00:00:21.492 --> 00:00:24.964
Business and this episode were gonna
be taking a look at planning to

9
00:00:24.964 --> 00:00:26.887
deploy Windows Hello for Business.

10
00:00:26.887 --> 00:00:30.447
And believe me you don't want to cut
corners on the planning stage wanna make

11
00:00:30.447 --> 00:00:32.403
sure we have a good
idea of what to expect.

12
00:00:32.403 --> 00:00:35.331
And here in the studio to help
me with what to expect is Mr.

13
00:00:35.331 --> 00:00:36.750
Mike Stephens Microsoft.

14
00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:37.930
Mike thank you for joining us.

15
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:39.590
>> Thanks Don, it's great to be here.

16
00:00:39.590 --> 00:00:42.210
>> All right and what are we gonna
be looking at here in this episode?

17
00:00:42.210 --> 00:00:46.510
>> So in this episode we're gonna really
focus on the planning of Windows Hello

18
00:00:46.510 --> 00:00:47.280
deployment.

19
00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:50.730
Distributed systems can
be quite intimidating and

20
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:55.400
the thing we wanna do is prepare you
guys to know how to set this thing up.

21
00:00:55.400 --> 00:00:58.900
And don't get intimidated by all the knobs
and the servers that you're moving to.

22
00:00:58.900 --> 00:01:02.050
And the way to do that is to
be prepared is just plan,

23
00:01:02.050 --> 00:01:04.590
I mean there's no cutting
corners around it.

24
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:08.400
So today we're gonna talk about
the different deployment models,

25
00:01:08.400 --> 00:01:10.780
we're gonna talk about the trust models.

26
00:01:10.780 --> 00:01:14.140
That's a key one cuz we always get
questions about the trust models.

27
00:01:14.140 --> 00:01:16.272
We're gonna into actual,

28
00:01:16.272 --> 00:01:22.420
what we're going to focus these series
of shows on is the on-prem model.

29
00:01:22.420 --> 00:01:26.146
And then we're gonna talk about
like the deployment strategy,

30
00:01:26.146 --> 00:01:30.700
where we'll just give a very high-level
overview of what we're going to do in

31
00:01:30.700 --> 00:01:32.770
the next episodes from here on out.

32
00:01:32.770 --> 00:01:36.636
So getting into that, we'll jump right on
in with the actual deployment options.

33
00:01:36.636 --> 00:01:39.476
So Windows Hello for
Business has two deployment options,

34
00:01:39.476 --> 00:01:42.386
there's a hybrid option that's
been out for quite a while.

35
00:01:42.386 --> 00:01:47.234
And then there's an on premises model,
or what we call on prem for short,

36
00:01:47.234 --> 00:01:52.023
and the hybrid model's been out since
about Nov 15 with that release.

37
00:01:52.023 --> 00:01:53.965
And that one is mainly for,

38
00:01:53.965 --> 00:01:59.303
well when you have hybrid in our terms
is that I have on premises resources.

39
00:01:59.303 --> 00:02:02.757
So I have file shares and printers and
things of that nature that

40
00:02:02.757 --> 00:02:05.638
I need to access and
then I have the Cloud resources.

41
00:02:05.638 --> 00:02:06.931
So I have Office 365,

42
00:02:06.931 --> 00:02:11.068
I'm doing some stuff in a Azure I might
have some line of business apps in Azure.

43
00:02:11.068 --> 00:02:16.482
So I need to have that authentication
that spans both the hybrid model,

44
00:02:16.482 --> 00:02:18.656
or the cloud and the on prem.

45
00:02:18.656 --> 00:02:21.498
And I wanna do that,
I don't wanna sign in twice, so

46
00:02:21.498 --> 00:02:24.810
I wanna sign in with one credential
that gets me both places.

47
00:02:25.940 --> 00:02:28.200
>> Now,
I know when it comes to choosing a model,

48
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:29.730
that's always a challenge for people.

49
00:02:29.730 --> 00:02:33.590
And a lot of us hear about,
you need to push into the cloud or

50
00:02:33.590 --> 00:02:39.490
do a managed system center type
deployment, or do a standalone deployment.

51
00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:43.700
How do we pick which model is really
the most appropriate for our organization?

52
00:02:43.700 --> 00:02:48.340
>> So that's an excellent question and
we get that a lot, basically the best

53
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:53.380
way to tell is if you can use hybrid or
on prem is to look at your directory.

54
00:02:53.380 --> 00:02:55.330
If you're using Azure AD Connect,

55
00:02:55.330 --> 00:02:59.710
which is a directory synchronization tool
that you get when you federate with Azure.

56
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:04.070
Then you're going to be hybrid, there's
no questions about it because what's

57
00:03:04.070 --> 00:03:08.560
happening is you're either synchronizing
your identities or credentials,

58
00:03:08.560 --> 00:03:10.550
which is the identity and the password.

59
00:03:10.550 --> 00:03:14.070
You're synchronizing those into
your Azure cloud directory, and

60
00:03:14.070 --> 00:03:19.390
then what happens there is just that
the on prem configuration knows

61
00:03:19.390 --> 00:03:21.130
that you're federated at that point.

62
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:23.990
And so what happens is some of
the components that we'll talk about

63
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:26.490
like device registration and
key registration.

64
00:03:26.490 --> 00:03:31.300
Those are no longer targeted to
the on premises infrastructure.

65
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:35.400
There's configuration in Active Directory
that says, hey, you're a hybrid customer,

66
00:03:35.400 --> 00:03:38.280
we need to redirect you
to those endpoints.

67
00:03:38.280 --> 00:03:40.670
So basically,
that's the easiest way to do it, Don,

68
00:03:40.670 --> 00:03:43.880
is if you're going to be federated or
you are federated and

69
00:03:43.880 --> 00:03:48.190
you're using Azure AD Connect,
then the hybrid model is for you.

70
00:03:48.190 --> 00:03:52.307
The alternative to the hybrid model,
which is great, and we've gotten tons of

71
00:03:52.307 --> 00:03:56.057
feedback which is what we've been
working on in the creator's update,

72
00:03:56.057 --> 00:03:57.907
was people wanted an on prem model.

73
00:03:57.907 --> 00:04:00.733
It's like they recognize
the value of cloud,

74
00:04:00.733 --> 00:04:03.557
but we're not ready to get there just yet
and so

75
00:04:03.557 --> 00:04:08.285
what we wanted to do is because we really
have a main concern about passwords.

76
00:04:08.285 --> 00:04:12.335
We want people off of passwords, and we
won't even have the people who are still

77
00:04:12.335 --> 00:04:15.611
waiting and getting ready for
the cloud to get off of passwords.

78
00:04:15.611 --> 00:04:19.759
And so what we wanna do there is have
an on premises version of this where it

79
00:04:19.759 --> 00:04:22.208
works with most of your infrastructure and

80
00:04:22.208 --> 00:04:25.880
you can set it up with the things
you know, as we did in the intro,

81
00:04:25.880 --> 00:04:29.704
just the tools and things that
you've already invested in there.

82
00:04:29.704 --> 00:04:33.865
And so that's where the on premises
model came in and to be clear that

83
00:04:33.865 --> 00:04:38.910
is a new model that only the creators
update client in Windows 10 supports.

84
00:04:38.910 --> 00:04:42.330
So you still have the hybrid
model you can go to, and

85
00:04:42.330 --> 00:04:46.670
it works really well, but now what we're
introducing and really trying to hope

86
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:50.150
enterprises that are waiting to make
that jump to the cloud is now there's

87
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:54.150
an affordable two factor authentication
solution that they can go to.

88
00:04:54.150 --> 00:04:56.970
>> And I know one of the concerns that
a lot of people have is some people

89
00:04:56.970 --> 00:04:59.730
are just not comfortable putting
information out in the cloud.

90
00:04:59.730 --> 00:05:03.300
And they want it to be on premises,
and when we talk about simple data,

91
00:05:03.300 --> 00:05:05.310
like a website,
people get really nervous about that.

92
00:05:05.310 --> 00:05:08.760
But when you talk about authentication,
that's big deal,

93
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:11.490
that is literally the keys to the kingdom.

94
00:05:11.490 --> 00:05:14.460
And so it comes down to what your
company is comfortable with, and

95
00:05:14.460 --> 00:05:16.910
ready to accept or
what you've already accepted.

96
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:20.130
And part of this is really gonna be
influenced by what trust models you'll

97
00:05:20.130 --> 00:05:21.030
accept, right?

98
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:23.060
And so, let's talk a little
bit about the trust models.

99
00:05:23.060 --> 00:05:27.430
>> Right, so, the trust models
are really great, because if you are in

100
00:05:27.430 --> 00:05:32.800
these particular trust models,
people get confused.

101
00:05:32.800 --> 00:05:36.640
So the best way to explain these is first
of all, is let's look at the hybrid.

102
00:05:36.640 --> 00:05:38.010
And say for

103
00:05:38.010 --> 00:05:43.030
when you authenticate to Azure, you're
always authenticating to Azure with a key.

104
00:05:43.030 --> 00:05:47.420
So, there's no worry about there,
the trust models really focus on

105
00:05:47.420 --> 00:05:52.040
how you authenticate to your on-prem
infrastructure, your Active Directory.

106
00:05:52.040 --> 00:05:56.870
And that's the key thing, is the hybrid
model, the deployment models talk about

107
00:05:56.870 --> 00:06:00.840
where are your resources that you're
accessing, so cloud or on prem.

108
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:04.990
And then the trust model is
how do I authenticate on prem?

109
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:09.780
And we have two trust models there, and
those trust models are key trust and

110
00:06:09.780 --> 00:06:11.460
we also have certificate trust.

111
00:06:11.460 --> 00:06:14.070
And we'll go into those because
there's the nuances here

112
00:06:14.070 --> 00:06:16.186
that get very confusing for people.

113
00:06:16.186 --> 00:06:19.400
And so we wanna make sure that
we explain it really well so

114
00:06:19.400 --> 00:06:21.480
that you can plan which one's best for
you.

115
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:22.870
They both work really good,

116
00:06:22.870 --> 00:06:27.170
it's just kind of like a choose
your own poison kinda speak there.

117
00:06:27.170 --> 00:06:30.570
So, whatever flavor you like,
that's what you can be able to do, and

118
00:06:30.570 --> 00:06:33.360
we did this to meet the needs
of all enterprises.

119
00:06:33.360 --> 00:06:37.855
So let's jump in the key trust here, and
so, the key trust model is just that.

120
00:06:37.855 --> 00:06:43.150
It's you authenticate to your on-prem
active directory using a key, so

121
00:06:43.150 --> 00:06:45.490
you'll sign in the way
you normally sign in.

122
00:06:45.490 --> 00:06:46.620
You'll use a PIN or

123
00:06:46.620 --> 00:06:49.820
your bio metric because you're
using Windows Hello for Business.

124
00:06:49.820 --> 00:06:53.830
And then in the background you still use
Curveros to authenticate, it's just that

125
00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:57.590
instead of using that password or
that symmetric key and all that,

126
00:06:57.590 --> 00:07:01.660
you're just using a key that was generated
during your Windows Hello provisioning.

127
00:07:01.660 --> 00:07:06.690
Now there's a got you to this Don,
is that to use

128
00:07:06.690 --> 00:07:11.790
key trust it does require
a Windows Server 2016 domain controller.

129
00:07:11.790 --> 00:07:13.510
Now it doesn't need all of them so

130
00:07:13.510 --> 00:07:18.640
we don't change the domain function
level or the force function level.

131
00:07:18.640 --> 00:07:21.340
That's a big thing that we know
customers don't like to do.

132
00:07:21.340 --> 00:07:24.640
We don't wanna change those
functional levels, but

133
00:07:24.640 --> 00:07:27.750
you do need to have the 2016
domain controller because,

134
00:07:27.750 --> 00:07:31.970
well it's the only one that knows how
to authenticate a key trust model.

135
00:07:31.970 --> 00:07:36.620
So what will happen is, is that you need
to have an adequate number of those domain

136
00:07:36.620 --> 00:07:41.740
controllers in order for you to be
able to authenticate all of the users.

137
00:07:41.740 --> 00:07:45.330
Adequate, we don't really have
a silver bullet term for adequate,

138
00:07:45.330 --> 00:07:47.470
because we don't know
everybody's environment.

139
00:07:47.470 --> 00:07:51.414
You basically need to look at the existing
authentication, and the amount of load

140
00:07:51.414 --> 00:07:54.859
that all of your domain controllers
are doing as people authenticate.

141
00:07:54.859 --> 00:07:56.937
Because what people may not realize is,

142
00:07:56.937 --> 00:08:01.281
as soon as you insert that 2016 domain
controller in your environment It becomes

143
00:08:01.281 --> 00:08:05.644
the workhorse of the entire environment
and people say, well, why is that, Mike?

144
00:08:05.644 --> 00:08:07.600
And I go well, if you look at it,

145
00:08:07.600 --> 00:08:12.920
the 2016 domain controller knows
how to authenticate everybody.

146
00:08:12.920 --> 00:08:15.540
But the down levels,
like the 2012, 2012 R2,

147
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:19.368
they only know how to do
everything prior to 2016.

148
00:08:19.368 --> 00:08:24.009
So instantly, your existing authentication
is going to be distributed across all

149
00:08:24.009 --> 00:08:26.728
domain controllers, but
your Windows Hello for

150
00:08:26.728 --> 00:08:29.795
Business authentication is
gonna be targeted there.

151
00:08:29.795 --> 00:08:34.330
And so this is where I have a little Visio
here, we can show you, just to make sure

152
00:08:34.330 --> 00:08:39.231
that people understand here, is that the
authentication model is always on-prem.

153
00:08:39.231 --> 00:08:44.076
And in here, you show that the user
is authenticating to a 2016

154
00:08:44.076 --> 00:08:46.930
domain controller and it uses a key.

155
00:08:46.930 --> 00:08:50.610
And so anytime you hear key trust,
you need to

156
00:08:50.610 --> 00:08:54.830
understand that that means you're
going to need 2016 domain controllers.

157
00:08:54.830 --> 00:09:00.800
Now, the pro to this model is you don't
need to issue certificates to your users.

158
00:09:00.800 --> 00:09:04.500
Users will just generate a key,
that key will be protected in TPM, but

159
00:09:04.500 --> 00:09:08.060
you don't need to issue
certificates to the users.

160
00:09:08.060 --> 00:09:12.610
So really, what you have here in this
particular key trust model is which

161
00:09:12.610 --> 00:09:14.640
one do you like the most or
like the least.

162
00:09:14.640 --> 00:09:18.351
In that case is,
are you okay with 2016 domain controllers?

163
00:09:18.351 --> 00:09:23.940
Or are you okay with issuing
certificates to your end users?

164
00:09:23.940 --> 00:09:26.150
And that leads us to
the next model that we have,

165
00:09:26.150 --> 00:09:28.340
which is the certificate trust model.

166
00:09:28.340 --> 00:09:32.500
In the certificate trust model,
I have another diagram for this one here,

167
00:09:32.500 --> 00:09:37.588
we can just intro here,
go to that slide there, here we go.

168
00:09:37.588 --> 00:09:42.680
So in the certificate trust model,
as expected, remember its always on-prem,

169
00:09:42.680 --> 00:09:46.040
as you always authenticate to with a key.

170
00:09:46.040 --> 00:09:50.570
This one, you're actually going to
issue a certificate to your end users.

171
00:09:50.570 --> 00:09:54.490
So when you issue a certificate,
now, this is just normal

172
00:09:54.490 --> 00:09:59.020
smart card authentication that Windows
has been doing for the last 15, 17 years.

173
00:09:59.020 --> 00:10:03.800
So you don't have a dependency on
that 2016 domain controller anymore.

174
00:10:03.800 --> 00:10:08.790
So the two models can help nearly
any enterprise whatsoever in

175
00:10:08.790 --> 00:10:13.730
how they want to deploy and
whether they wanna issue certificates, or

176
00:10:13.730 --> 00:10:17.280
if they're fine with keys, or whether they
don't want 2016 domain controllers, or

177
00:10:17.280 --> 00:10:18.580
whether they're okay with that.

178
00:10:18.580 --> 00:10:23.190
It's really, wherever the pain is, there's
a model that will offset that pain.

179
00:10:23.190 --> 00:10:26.620
>> Now, is it possible to do both, or
do we have to pick one or the other?

180
00:10:26.620 --> 00:10:28.150
>> It is possible to do both.

181
00:10:28.150 --> 00:10:30.980
But you need to understand that the
management overhead that you're gonna have

182
00:10:30.980 --> 00:10:33.770
is just trying to keep track of
which user is a cert trust user, and

183
00:10:33.770 --> 00:10:35.570
which user is a key trust user.

184
00:10:35.570 --> 00:10:36.600
But you certainly can.

185

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss configuring a Microsoft public key infrastructure (PKI) to support Windows Hello for Business. They discuss some of the certificates that are required, and then demonstrate configuring certificate templates to provide them.
episodes.title: Preparing the PKI

So for those people who don't, Don,

25

I think we have some videos that they
can look at and some episodes, right?

26
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:12.665
>> Absolutely, yeah.

31

32

some of our other shows like 70-414

33

We have a great section in there that
explains how to design a PKI and

34

that design is really important.

35
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:43.184
Because there's a right way and a wrong
way, and unfortunately the right way is

36
00:01:43.184 --> 00:01:45.960
different for different organizations and
the way you intend to use it.

37
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.300
So be sure to check out those shows for

38

And then the 70-412 show for

39
00:01:53.640 --> 00:01:57.530
It actually shows how to set up this CA

So if you haven't worked with PKIs at all,

42

But the neat part about a PKI is how
flexible it is, and how it can be used for

43
00:02:05.805 --> 00:02:07.496
numerous different solutions.

44
00:02:07.496 --> 00:02:10.970
So if you've already got a PKI in place
you don't have to roll a new one out.

45
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:15.353
We can just take the existing PKI and
get it to work with Windows Hello for

46
00:02:15.353 --> 00:02:16.608
Business, right?

47
00:02:16.608 --> 00:02:20.039
>> Absolutely, like you said,
there's numerous uses out there.

48
00:02:20.039 --> 00:02:22.030
Skype for Business uses it.

49
00:02:22.030 --> 00:02:25.295
Nearly everything today is using PKI,
VPNs use PKI.

50
00:02:25.295 --> 00:02:29.493
So what we're gonna do today is,
we're just going to enhance or

51
00:02:29.493 --> 00:02:33.405
extend the use of the PKI to
issue different certificates.

52
00:02:33.405 --> 00:02:35.496
And the reason why we need
to do those is because,

53
00:02:35.496 --> 00:02:37.340
well that's what this episode's about.

54
00:02:37.340 --> 00:02:41.020
So the first thing I wanna do is go to
my screen, we're gonna jump right in.

55
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:42.965
And I'm on a domain controller,

56
00:02:42.965 --> 00:02:46.518
and I'm gonna move to my
certificate authority right here.

57
00:02:46.518 --> 00:02:48.400
Yep, you got the CA in the corner here.

58
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:52.726
And because we're going to be doing a lot

59
00:02:52.726 --> 00:02:56.644
basically I'm gonna first start out

60
00:02:56.644 --> 00:02:59.757
this certificate authority

61
00:02:59.757 --> 00:03:03.230
Because well I don't

Okay, so now that I have the certificate

64
00:03:11.230 --> 00:03:15.590
And you're gonna see, here's our CA and

65
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:19.070
And so we're gonna do a lot of work in
here throughout all the episodes, but

66
00:03:19.070 --> 00:03:20.620
in this particular episode.

67
00:03:20.620 --> 00:03:24.652
We're gonna use the certificate template
manager, and it's a little thing that's

68
00:03:24.652 --> 00:03:27.848

69
00:03:27.848 --> 00:03:30.607
And so these are all the different
certificate templates that you

70
00:03:30.607 --> 00:03:31.320

71
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:34.020
And so
what we're gonna do is we're actually

72

gonna duplicate a certificate template.

73
00:03:36.170 --> 00:03:37.573
We're gonna create a copy of it, and

74
00:03:37.573 --> 00:03:39.984
then we're gonna change some of
those characteristics of it.

75
00:03:39.984 --> 00:03:42.272
Now just again,
another word of caution here,

76
00:03:42.272 --> 00:03:44.684
make sure that you validate
all of these changes.

77
00:03:44.684 --> 00:03:47.963
And if you're in a production environment
before you just go through and

78
00:03:47.963 --> 00:03:48.780
do these things.

79
00:03:48.780 --> 00:03:52.512
We wanna make sure that if you change
a template or if you unpublish one.

80
00:03:52.512 --> 00:03:53.613
Or anything like that,

81
00:03:53.613 --> 00:03:56.710
we don't wanna cause any outages
in the production environment.

82
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:02.254
So what I'm going to look for
here is the Kerberos Authentication.

83
00:04:02.254 --> 00:04:06.371
And this guy right here, this is the new
domain controller certificate that

00:04:06.371 --> 00:04:10.491
deprecates the domain controller and
domain controller authentication,

85
00:04:10.491 --> 00:04:11.480
the ones up here.

86
00:04:11.480 --> 00:04:15.490
So we're gonna make a copy of this guy
here, and we'll do it by duplicating that.

87
00:04:15.490 --> 00:04:18.786
Now, as you can see here this is
the properties of the template we

88
00:04:18.786 --> 00:04:21.546
don't have any name for
it yet or anything like that.

89
00:04:21.546 --> 00:04:24.825
And this what this does is that it
actually controls the UA setting.

90
00:04:24.825 --> 00:04:29.737
So that if you have a 2003, but an XP,
or it allows you to manipulate UI

91
00:04:29.737 --> 00:04:34.814
settings in a way were you don't create
a certificate template that asks for

92
00:04:34.814 --> 00:04:39.620
features of ACA or a client,
that doesn't have those features.

93
00:04:39.620 --> 00:04:42.500
So in this episode,
we're gonna do everything here,

94
00:04:42.500 --> 00:04:46.200
we're gonna do with 2012 R2CA,
that's the one I'm running.

95
00:04:46.200 --> 00:04:47.494
And I'm gonna go ahead and select this.

96
00:04:47.494 --> 00:04:51.058
And now what you see here is a pop up
that's saying, hey, I'm gonna tell you

97
00:04:51.058 --> 00:04:54.750
the changes that you made by
selecting this particular CA version.

98
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:55.985
And that's fine, this is great.

99
00:04:55.985 --> 00:04:59.180
And it's really good to let you know
what things change or don't change.

100
00:04:59.180 --> 00:05:00.864
But for this, we're gonna go ahead and

101
00:05:00.864 --> 00:05:03.070
we don't wanna be prompted
with that all the time.

102
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:06.290
So we're gonna basically
uncheck this box here,

103
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:11.207
so that we can breeze through these and
set these to 2012 in Windows A1.

104
00:05:11.207 --> 00:05:15.396
So now we're going to go the General tab,
and in here you can see that it just gives

105
00:05:15.396 --> 00:05:18.072
us a real name like copy
Kerberos Authentication.

106
00:05:18.072 --> 00:05:20.078
We're gonna go ahead and
give that a new name.

107
00:05:20.078 --> 00:05:23.916
We're gonna call that domain controller
authentication, but we're going

108
00:05:23.916 --> 00:05:27.740
to put a little bracket here that says
Kerberos, so we know its different.

109
00:05:27.740 --> 00:05:34.558
So we do command
controller authentication,

110
00:05:34.558 --> 00:05:37.539
did I do a caps lock?

111
00:05:37.539 --> 00:05:39.520
And we'll just do Kerberos here.

112
00:05:41.630 --> 00:05:44.413
And in here, you can see where you
have your validity period, and

113
00:05:44.413 --> 00:05:45.381
your renewal period.

114
00:05:45.381 --> 00:05:47.560
And we're gonna leave those the same here.

115
00:05:47.560 --> 00:05:50.507
And then what we're going to do is
go to the subject part of this.

116
00:05:50.507 --> 00:05:53.180
This is this tab up here
called subject name.

117
00:05:53.180 --> 00:05:56.540
Now as you can see in here this is
already pre-selected for us, and

118
00:05:56.540 --> 00:05:58.460
we're not gonna change any of these.

119
00:05:58.460 --> 00:06:00.190
This is exactly what we want here.

120
00:06:00.190 --> 00:06:03.590
So the things to look for
here is to just leave everything is.

121
00:06:03.590 --> 00:06:05.960
But we wanna make sure that
the DNS name right here,

122
00:06:05.960 --> 00:06:07.770
this guy right here, is checked.

123
00:06:07.770 --> 00:06:10.031
We wanna make sure
the DNS name is checked.

124
00:06:10.031 --> 00:06:14.635
That's critical to make sure the domain
controller has the proper DNS name for

125
00:06:14.635 --> 00:06:16.179
when it does validation.

126
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:21.811
And then the next one we wanna go to
is the Security tab, which is over,

127
00:06:21.811 --> 00:06:22.803
this guy here.

128
00:06:22.803 --> 00:06:25.736
No, sorry the Cryptography,
that's what we want.

129
00:06:25.736 --> 00:06:30.970
In the Cryptography,
this is set up very compatible.

130
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:35.188
This is using a very old version
of cryptography that Windows used,

131
00:06:35.188 --> 00:06:38.375
what we call the CryptoAPI,
or for short cappy 1.

132
00:06:38.375 --> 00:06:40.709
While this is still really good crypto,

133
00:06:40.709 --> 00:06:43.835
it's not the modern crypto
that we're using today.

134
00:06:43.835 --> 00:06:47.704
And so what we wanna do is switch this
template over to use our more modern

135
00:06:47.704 --> 00:06:48.616
cryptography.

136
00:06:48.616 --> 00:06:51.771
Which is perfectly works great
on any of the current operating

137
00:06:51.771 --> 00:06:54.660
systems that are supported
by Microsoft today.

138
00:06:54.660 --> 00:06:57.900
So how we do that is we're
gonna go up to this provider.

139
00:06:57.900 --> 00:07:00.708
And we're gonna select
Key Storage Provider, and

140
00:07:00.708 --> 00:07:02.607
now you get a change in the screen.

141
00:07:02.607 --> 00:07:06.982
And what that does is that moves us
over to what we call the crypto,

142
00:07:06.982 --> 00:07:09.783
next gen or
you might see it in MSDN as CNG.

143
00:07:09.783 --> 00:07:11.640
This is the modern cryptography, and

144
00:07:11.640 --> 00:07:15.534
this is the stuff that we're continuing
to innovate by adding new algorithms.

145
00:07:15.534 --> 00:07:19.490
Like elliptic curves and things of that
nature, so we wanna switch over to this.

146
00:07:19.490 --> 00:07:21.920
We're gonna leave the algorithm
name just the way it is.

147
00:07:21.920 --> 00:07:25.958
We wanna use an RSA, and the minimum
key size is totally fine there.

148
00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:29.206
What we do wanna do is because
of the notes of SHA-1,

149
00:07:29.206 --> 00:07:34.690
we wanna bring this guy down to
SHA-256 just for good crypto hygiene.

150
00:07:34.690 --> 00:07:38.930
And then after that we're gonna
go to this one tab here which is

151
00:07:38.930 --> 00:07:43.340
probably new to a lot of people,
which is the superceded tab.

152
00:07:43.340 --> 00:07:46.690
Now what superceded does is a lot
of times in your environment,

153
00:07:46.690 --> 00:07:52.480
you'll run into a time where it's like
well, we had certificate template one.

154
00:07:52.480 --> 00:07:56.238
And now we need upgraded or
updated to where we now need to have

155
00:07:56.238 --> 00:08:00.008
certificate template 2 replace
certificate template 1.

156
00:08:00.008 --> 00:08:03.201
And that's what the superceded
tab allows us to do.

157
00:08:03.201 --> 00:08:07.866
Is what we can do is we can put in
different template names within

158
00:08:07.866 --> 00:08:10.427
this part of this configuration.

159
00:08:10.427 --> 00:08:13.035
And then what it will do is is
that we have auto enrollment

160
00:08:13.035 --> 00:08:16.197
piece that we will get to a little
later in this episode that will just

161
00:08:16.197 --> 00:08:18.990
magically switch
the certificate templates out.

162
00:08:18.990 --> 00:08:23.860
So it will request a certificate from
the new one and replace the old one.

163
00:08:23.860 --> 00:08:27.800
So in here because we wanna make sure
that we get the most current and

164
00:08:27.800 --> 00:08:29.880
the most secure certificate template,

165
00:08:29.880 --> 00:08:33.940
we're gonna add those old ones
that I showed you, into this list.

166
00:08:33.940 --> 00:08:37.760
And so this one is gonna start with,
the domain controller one.

167
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:40.690
And I'd like love this to be multiselect,
but unfortunately it's not.

168
00:08:40.690 --> 00:08:42.670
So we're gonna do them one at a time here.

169
00:08:42.670 --> 00:08:46.280
So I'm gonna add the domain controller,
and then I'm gonna go back down.

170
00:08:46.280 --> 00:08:52.710
And I'm gonna add the domain controller
authentication guy here, right here.

171
00:08:52.710 --> 00:08:57.938
And then the last one is, we're gonna
add the Kerberos Authentication,

172
00:08:57.938 --> 00:09:00.732
the one that we actually took a copy of.

173
00:09:00.732 --> 00:09:03.524
And the reason why we do that is just,
as we said,

174
00:09:03.524 --> 00:09:06.570
that one was using some
of the older crypto.

175
00:09:06.570 --> 00:09:08.242
And so in using the older crypto,

176
00:09:08.242 --> 00:09:10.945
we wana move everybody up
to the most current crypto.

177
00:09:10.945 --> 00:09:12.579
That's the stuff that
is being optimized and

178
00:09:12.579 --> 00:09:15.410
that's the stuff that's being
innovated moving forward.

179
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:20.380
So we have that going there for
us a and now basically we're done.

180
00:09:20.380 --> 00:09:27.120
So now we have to do, is hit OK, and now
we have stuff down here as you can see.

181
00:09:27.120 --> 00:09:32.362
We have our new Domain Controller
Authentication Certificate template.

182
00:09:32.362 --> 00:09:35.186
>> And any new domain controller that we
bring in is gonna automatically grab that,

183
00:09:35.186 --> 00:09:36.444
so we don't have to worry about it.

184
00:09:36.444 --> 00:09:38.970
The old ones,
it'll just be when they renew?

185
00:09:38.970 --> 00:09:40.086
>> That'll happen later.

186
00:09:40.086 --> 00:09:43.118
What we're gonna do there is when we
get near the end of this episode,

187
00:09:43.118 --> 00:09:44.940
we've got one more template to create.

188
00:09:44.940 --> 00:09:46.779
And after we create that template,

189
00:09:46.779 --> 00:09:50.042
we're gonna do something called
deploying auto enrollment.

190
00:09:50.042 --> 00:09:54.554
But you're right, in the old school
days back in Windows 2000, 2003 even

191
00:09:54.554 --> 00:09:59.850
2012 today, they will automatically look
for that domain controller certificate.

192
00:09:59.850 --> 00:10:04.105
And they just go ahead and grab it, and
they try to do that for an ease of use.

193
00:10:04.105 --> 00:10:08.670
Back when they did that, when that design
was functional, it worked very well.

194
00:10:08.670 --> 00:10:11.883
I said but nowadays, it's like we
really need to actually upgrade those

195
00:10:11.883 --> 00:10:13.474
domain controller certificates.

196
00:10:13.474 --> 00:10:17.045
And we can't necessarily do that,
just flat out change that philosophy or

197
00:10:17.045 --> 00:10:20.110
change that model now,
we would break a lot of people.

198
00:10:20.110 --> 00:10:24.000
So what we do is we will deploy auto
enrollment to our domain controllers.

199
00:10:24.000 --> 00:10:28.873
And what auto enrollment will do for us is
that it'll actually automatically go out,

200
00:10:28.873 --> 00:10:32.945
read those superceded settings,
go read that certificate template.

201
00:10:32.945 --> 00:10:35.372
And then it'll switch those out for
us so that way,

202
00:10:35.372 --> 00:10:38.200
we don't have to worry about
actually requesting search.

203
00:10:38.200 --> 00:10:41.056
Domain controllers will just get
the certificates on their own.

204
00:10:41.056 --> 00:10:42.851
But more importantly, the bigger part,

205
00:10:42.851 --> 00:10:45.210
is they'll just renew
the certificate on their own.

206
00:10:45.210 --> 00:10:49.300
Which is where people usually get a little
frightened is that certificate expires and

207
00:10:49.300 --> 00:10:50.720
they didn't know what happened.

208
00:10:50.720 --> 00:10:53.607
So let's go ahead and
make our web server one.

209
00:10:53.607 --> 00:10:55.814
And so we're gonna do a very
similar function here,

210
00:10:55.814 --> 00:10:58.240
where we're gonna go down
here to our web server.

211
00:10:58.240 --> 00:11:01.152
And we're gonna say
duplicate template here, and

212
00:11:01.152 --> 00:11:03.461
we're gonna uncheck these boxes here.

213
00:11:03.461 --> 00:11:07.389
And put everything down to 2012,
so that way we have it.

214
00:11:07.389 --> 00:11:11.850
And we'll give it a name and we're just
gonna call it Internal Web Server.

215
00:11:13.510 --> 00:11:17.850
And again, you can adjust your validity
periods and your renewals as you like.

216
00:11:19.300 --> 00:11:22.820
And we're gonna go to
the Request Handling part.

217
00:11:22.820 --> 00:11:27.847
And now what the Request Handling does, is
that when a CA gets a certificate request.

218
00:11:27.847 --> 00:11:34.599
This is telling the certificate authority,
based on asking for this template.

219
00:11:34.599 --> 00:11:37.300
How do you want me to handle
the certificate request here?

220
00:11:37.300 --> 00:11:39.890
And you have things like signature
encryption and purpose and

221
00:11:39.890 --> 00:11:41.330
things of this nature.

222
00:11:41.330 --> 00:11:46.128
One of the things that you do is with
TLS search is it's very common for

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike continue discussing the configuration of a Microsoft PKI. 271
00:13:20.240 --> 00:13:22.840
But stay tuned because we've got

Business coming up.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike complete the configuration of Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS). Mike demonstrates how to use Group Managed Service Accounts to better secure ADFS. Finally, Mike demonstrates configuring the Device Registration Service (DRS)

>> [LAUGH]

ADFS is installed, now we just

And while sometimes that can

00:00:59.155 --> 00:01:00.960
here it's really not that bad.

24
00:01:00.960 --> 00:01:02.680
>> Yeah, it's not gonna be that bad Don.

25
00:01:02.680 --> 00:01:05.350
I mean, we're gonna have a good
time here with configuring this.

26
00:01:05.350 --> 00:01:08.440
We're going to talk about some of
the different ways to install ADFS.

27
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:11.650
Depending on your environment,
we'll have some dependencies on how

28
00:01:11.650 --> 00:01:14.380
you're gonna do your service account,
so forth like that.

29
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:17.040
We'll also be talking about
the actual configuration point,

30
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:20.100
which is just really
the barebones ADFS setup.

31
00:01:20.100 --> 00:01:23.560
We won't have to dive into any of that,
creating claims and

32
00:01:23.560 --> 00:01:24.980
all these other things there.

33
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:25.750
So we'll do that.

34
00:01:25.750 --> 00:01:27.820
And then we'll start doing
some permissioning things.

35
00:01:27.820 --> 00:01:31.170
We're gonna add some groups and
user accounts, and so forth, like that.

36
00:01:31.170 --> 00:01:33.200
So it's gonna be a really
good fun thing here.

37
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:34.200
So, let's get started.

38
00:01:34.200 --> 00:01:36.870
And the first thing we
have to do is talk about

39
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:39.760
the service account
the ADFS is gonna run on.

40
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:45.065
ADFS is able to run on either
a 2008 environment or later.

41
00:01:45.065 --> 00:01:46.104
But in 2012,

42
00:01:46.104 --> 00:01:50.408
Microsoft created these things called
group managed service accounts.

43
00:01:50.408 --> 00:01:54.850
And the benefit of those is that you
no longer manage the password yourself.

44
00:01:54.850 --> 00:01:58.397
You could actually allow the domain
controller to manage that password.

45
00:01:58.397 --> 00:02:02.360
And it's a high entry password,
and it changes on a regular basis.

46
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:06.863
And it wasn't like, when if you don't have
2012 domain controller, then you're back

47
00:02:06.863 --> 00:02:10.980
to creating those normal service accounts,
which are just regular user accounts.

48
00:02:10.980 --> 00:02:14.452
And then if you have password
policies which most companies do,

49
00:02:14.452 --> 00:02:18.261
then those accounts are gonna expire,
that passwords gonna expire.

50
00:02:18.261 --> 00:02:20.300
And then you're gonna
have service outages.

51
00:02:20.300 --> 00:02:23.000
And the last thing we don't want
people to do is just check that

52
00:02:23.000 --> 00:02:25.852
box that says password never
expire on your service accounts.

53
00:02:25.852 --> 00:02:27.105
That's just not a good idea at all.

54
00:02:27.105 --> 00:02:30.229
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what we really wanna do is this,

55
00:02:30.229 --> 00:02:34.190
get people to move towards those
group managed service accounts.

56
00:02:34.190 --> 00:02:37.010
And so what we're gonna do
here is we're gonna talk about

57
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:38.898
the group managed service accounts.

58
00:02:38.898 --> 00:02:43.397
We're gonna have a little bit different
set up depending on how you have those.

59
00:02:43.397 --> 00:02:47.550
Now, I'm gonna set it up as if we're in
a 2012 domain controller, which I have.

60
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:49.454
So we're gonna set it up
in the most secure way,

61
00:02:49.454 --> 00:02:51.507
which is using the group
managed service account.

62
00:02:51.507 --> 00:02:57.145
But along the way we're gonna talk about
what you might do if you only have a 2008,

63
00:02:57.145 --> 00:02:58.807
or 2008 R2 domain.

64
00:02:58.807 --> 00:03:01.350
And that way you'll at least
have the knowledge there.

65
00:03:01.350 --> 00:03:03.970
So the first thing we need to
do because we are going to

66
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:08.770
use the group manage service account,
is we need to prime the key distribution

67
00:03:08.770 --> 00:03:13.950
service that comes on every
Windows Server 2012 domain controller.

68
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:18.150
This key distribution services what makes
the group managed service account, or

69
00:03:18.150 --> 00:03:23.890
what we call GMSAs work so well is
because it uses keys that you provision.

70
00:03:23.890 --> 00:03:27.030
And the way that we do this is
we're gonna use a PowerShell cmdlet

71
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:31.540
on the actual domain controller to
prime that primary key to get it going.

72
00:03:31.540 --> 00:03:34.350
And then from there,
we'll be able to move forward.

73
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:37.130
So I'm gonna go to my domain
controller here that I have set up.

74
00:03:37.130 --> 00:03:40.240
And as you can see, I've already
got a PowerShell loaded up and

75
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:43.465
I do need to be domain admin,
because we're gonna be writing some.

76
00:03:43.465 --> 00:03:46.783
The results of this PowerShell cmdlet
are going to write some content in

77
00:03:46.783 --> 00:03:47.515
the Active Directory.

78
00:03:47.515 --> 00:03:50.245
So we need to make sure we
have that elevation there.

79
00:03:50.245 --> 00:03:53.725
And the command I've already got pre
pep because I can't type on camera.

80
00:03:53.725 --> 00:03:58.000
So what we're gonna do is I'm gonna paste
it there and then we're gonna explain it.

81
00:03:58.000 --> 00:04:02.250
So the PowerShell cmdlet what
we have is the Add-KdsRootKey.

82
00:04:02.250 --> 00:04:04.910
And the root key is basically,
it's the key which

83
00:04:04.910 --> 00:04:09.300
all other keys get derived of by this
KDS or key distribution service.

84
00:04:09.300 --> 00:04:12.100
This service is stateless,
it doesn't really store keys.

85
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:15.330
What it does is it has
this very complicated

86
00:04:15.330 --> 00:04:19.770
algorithm of deriving keys based on
a lot of different entropy factors.

87
00:04:19.770 --> 00:04:22.594
But before we do that,
it still needs to be seeded with a key.

88
00:04:22.594 --> 00:04:27.951
So what we have is the PowerShell
cmdlet of Add-KdsRootKey.

89
00:04:27.951 --> 00:04:31.974
And then we have the effective
time parameter that goes to that,

90
00:04:31.974 --> 00:04:36.580
now that effective time says,
when do we want this to be effective?

91
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:39.380
Because it's being written
to a domain controller.

92
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:40.970
So when we're writing
to a domain controller,

93
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:45.760
we have to think of AD replication and
when it's gonna be converging and

94
00:04:45.760 --> 00:04:48.470
the latency of AD replication conversions.

95
00:04:48.470 --> 00:04:52.460
So what we're doing in this
command here is we're kind of

96
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:56.200
cheating it a little bit where we say,
we're gonna back date this by

97
00:04:56.200 --> 00:05:01.020
adding a negative ten hours because
what happens in Active Directory is

98
00:05:01.020 --> 00:05:06.140
it doesn't really make this root
key available yet, until ten hours.

99
00:05:06.140 --> 00:05:06.730
So that way,

100
00:05:06.730 --> 00:05:10.900
it gives Active Directory time to
replicate that key out before it goes.

101
00:05:10.900 --> 00:05:13.500
We don't have ten hours to wait and so

102
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:15.400
what we're gonna do is
cheat it a little bit.

103
00:05:15.400 --> 00:05:17.324
So we're gonna run this command here.

104
00:05:17.324 --> 00:05:21.094
And we'll just throw the bill into here,
and you'll get back a GUID or GUID,

105
00:05:21.094 --> 00:05:22.143
as we like to call it.

106
00:05:22.143 --> 00:05:25.710
And this is just a way to mark this key.

107
00:05:25.710 --> 00:05:28.009
We don't need to know this information,
other than to say,

108
00:05:28.009 --> 00:05:31.310
if we don't get this response,
then we need to do some troubleshooting.

109
00:05:31.310 --> 00:05:34.750
Now, I will do the up arrow here and
say that if you were in a lab,

110
00:05:34.750 --> 00:05:36.400
you can use that same command.

111
00:05:36.400 --> 00:05:39.560
Or, they have this other one,
which is effective immediately.

112
00:05:39.560 --> 00:05:41.040
I typically don't use that one,

113
00:05:41.040 --> 00:05:43.400
but this is another way to where
you can type that command.

114
00:05:43.400 --> 00:05:47.910
But what we've done just there is we've
primed the KDS service with that root key.

115
00:05:47.910 --> 00:05:51.980
And we're now ready to go with
actually setting up ADFS,

116
00:05:51.980 --> 00:05:55.260
which we're going to use a group
managed service account to do so.

117
00:05:55.260 --> 00:06:00.450
So, I'm gonna switch over
to my ADFS machine here.

118
00:06:00.450 --> 00:06:04.040
And where we're at here, let's get
this other screen out of the way.

119
00:06:05.280 --> 00:06:07.320
So here we are with the ADFS.

120
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:10.110
And this is left off right where we had,
where we

121
00:06:10.110 --> 00:06:13.690
installed it in a previous episode and
we're ready to do some configuration.

122
00:06:13.690 --> 00:06:15.220
So in server manager,

123
00:06:15.220 --> 00:06:18.350
we have this nice little yellow
bang up here that we can go to.

124
00:06:18.350 --> 00:06:20.539
And it says, hey,
you need to configure your ADFS server.

125
00:06:20.539 --> 00:06:23.835
So we're gonna go ahead and just follow
the normal prompts that we have.

126
00:06:23.835 --> 00:06:28.270
And here, we're being asked, hey,
are you ready to create your ADFS.

127
00:06:28.270 --> 00:06:33.574
And we're gonna create a first federation
server and the federation server farm.

128
00:06:33.574 --> 00:06:36.480
So we'll go ahead and
click Next on this guy here.

129
00:06:36.480 --> 00:06:39.330
And I'm already logged in with
administrative credentials.

130
00:06:39.330 --> 00:06:41.230
Make sure that you are elevated there.

131
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:43.305
If not, you can change
the credentials using this prompt.

132
00:06:43.305 --> 00:06:46.920
And it'll ask you to pick a credential and
then, you'll have to go ahead and

133
00:06:46.920 --> 00:06:48.910
provide it with a username and password.

134
00:06:48.910 --> 00:06:50.410
But mine is already there.

135
00:06:50.410 --> 00:06:54.310
So we're gonna go a next step forward and
now here's some interesting things.

136
00:06:54.310 --> 00:06:58.560
In our previous episode,
we enrolled in for that SSL Certificate.

137
00:06:58.560 --> 00:07:02.580
And so now, we have to say what
SSL Certificate are we gonna use?

138
00:07:02.580 --> 00:07:06.430
And the thing is why we strategically
had you do it ahead of time

139
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:09.240
is if we go up to here to this pull-down,

140
00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:14.280
you can see that we have the ADFS
corp.contoso certificate right there.

141
00:07:14.280 --> 00:07:17.500
And so
that certificate is there ready to go.

142
00:07:17.500 --> 00:07:20.282
Now, what we have is
the federation service name.

143
00:07:20.282 --> 00:07:22.806
We need to TV timeout that
cuz that should be FS.

144
00:07:24.975 --> 00:07:33.695
[SOUND] Not quite sure why it picked up
that name and not subject alternate name.

145
00:07:36.404 --> 00:07:38.799
>> Okay,
it's got them both under the next name

146
00:07:38.799 --> 00:07:39.565
>> Yeah.

147
00:07:39.565 --> 00:07:42.920
Normally, it doesn't use that SSL search.

148
00:07:42.920 --> 00:07:45.080
So I haven't moved anything
>> Okay.

149
00:07:45.080 --> 00:07:49.590
>> So we can probably just pick up with-
>> Well, I can throw in a question.

150
00:07:49.590 --> 00:07:50.423
>> Yeah.
>> And I can say,

151
00:07:50.423 --> 00:07:53.362
now I remember from the last
episode we did fs.corp.whatever and

152
00:07:53.362 --> 00:07:57.497
then you can say [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, let's do that, my bad guys.

153
00:07:57.497 --> 00:08:02.458
I thought for sure it uses the fs, but
with all the different web certificates

154
00:08:02.458 --> 00:08:03.870
[INAUDIBLE]
>> Yeah.

155
00:08:03.870 --> 00:08:05.784
>> It is a point of confusion here, so.

156
00:08:05.784 --> 00:08:07.950
>> Yeah, I can throw in a question,
yeah perfect.

157
00:08:09.150 --> 00:08:10.550
>> Thank you, sir.

158
00:08:10.550 --> 00:08:11.121
>> Green light.

159
00:08:15.430 --> 00:08:19.066
Now Mike, not to interrupt you here too
much, but I remember the last episode when

160
00:08:19.066 --> 00:08:21.914
we created the certificate,
it was fs.corp.contoso.com,

161
00:08:21.914 --> 00:08:25.259
so the name here doesn't really match,
does it, what's going on there?

162
00:08:25.259 --> 00:08:28.209
>> You're right, Don,
the name doesn't match but what it is,

163
00:08:28.209 --> 00:08:30.840
is that we're looking for
federation service name.

164
00:08:30.840 --> 00:08:32.640
The ADFS is our host name.

165
00:08:32.640 --> 00:08:39.290
And the ADFS certificate is just pulling
the subject name out of the certificate.

166
00:08:39.290 --> 00:08:41.680
If we go down to
the federation service name,

167
00:08:41.680 --> 00:08:46.020
we'll see that poll down there
has the fscorp.contosa.com.

168
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:49.710
Now it's grabbing it off of the subject
alternate name, which is what we wanna

169
00:08:49.710 --> 00:08:54.428
be able to address the federation or the
farm of servers that you would have there.

170
00:08:54.428 --> 00:08:57.950
So, we're gonna use that there, and
then we have a little friendly field.

171
00:08:57.950 --> 00:09:01.301
I like to call these friendly or
happy UI fields, but

172
00:09:01.301 --> 00:09:03.900
we're gonna just say, contoso.com.

173
00:09:03.900 --> 00:09:08.276
It really doesn't matter, or
contoso.corporation here.

174
00:09:08.276 --> 00:09:10.080
Really, it doesn't matter
what you put in there but,

175
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:12.570
other than make sure you put
something that you want,

176
00:09:12.570 --> 00:09:15.250
your user should be able to see
cause that is what they'll see.

177
00:09:15.250 --> 00:09:17.770
>> This is like the barbarous
federation services.

178
00:09:17.770 --> 00:09:18.920
>> Yes.
>> A happy name.

179
00:09:18.920 --> 00:09:20.280
>> It's a happy tree name.

180
00:09:20.280 --> 00:09:22.050
Yes, absolutely here.

181
00:09:22.050 --> 00:09:26.560
So, we have this part of our specifying
the service properties ready to go.

182
00:09:26.560 --> 00:09:29.030
So now we're just gonna Next on
through this wizard here, and

183
00:09:29.030 --> 00:09:30.930
now here's the critical part here.

184
00:09:30.930 --> 00:09:34.420
If you're using 2012 Or 2012 R2,

185
00:09:34.420 --> 00:09:38.570
you have the ability to use that
group manage service account.

186
00:09:38.570 --> 00:09:40.900
And that's the way we should
always try to use that.

187
00:09:40.900 --> 00:09:45.520
If any service that you have whether it
be ADFS or any of the other ones, if they

188
00:09:45.520 --> 00:09:49.120
support group manage service accounts
it's highly encouraged that you use those

189
00:09:49.120 --> 00:09:53.480
accounts because they're just way more
secure, less overhead on your part.

190
00:09:53.480 --> 00:09:57.740
If, however, you haven't decided to make
that move yet to 2012 or 2012 R2, you're

191
00:09:57.740 --> 00:10:01.240
still okay, you go ahead and you would
check this bottom box down here that says,

192
00:10:01.240 --> 00:10:03.360
use an existing domain user account.

193
00:10:03.360 --> 00:10:06.670
And that's just a normal service account
that we've been using in Windows for,

194
00:10:06.670 --> 00:10:08.350
well, quite a while now.

195
00:10:08.350 --> 00:10:10.730
So, that's just gonna be your
normal user account, and

196
00:10:10.730 --> 00:10:12.880
you'll have to manage
that password separately.

197
00:10:12.880 --> 00:10:17.660
So, we're gonna use this top box here,
and we're gonna make it ideally,

198
00:10:17.660 --> 00:10:21.280
you wanna kind of have a little bit of
obfuscation with your service names,

199
00:10:21.280 --> 00:10:26.430
but for more clarity in the lab,
I'm just gonna name it ADFS SVC.

200
00:10:26.430 --> 00:10:29.650
And that's what it's gonna do, so that
way we know that that is a ADFS service

201
00:10:29.650 --> 00:10:32.980
account, and it'll be very visible
as we start trying to pick it out.

202
00:10:32.980 --> 00:10:35.920
Cuz we're gonna be adding this
account to several different groups.

203
00:10:35.920 --> 00:10:38.360
We're gonna be doing some permissions
to it, and so forth like that.

204
00:10:38.360 --> 00:10:41.490
So, we wanna be able to be
identify that pretty easily.

205
00:10:41.490 --> 00:10:43.670
So we have our account made,
we're ready to go there.

206
00:10:43.670 --> 00:10:45.122
Now, we're gonna go Next.

207
00:10:45.122 --> 00:10:49.322
Now, here comes back to that planning part
we talked about, where are you gonna use

208
00:10:49.322 --> 00:10:53.060
the Windows Internal Database or
are you gonna use a SQL Server?

209
00:10:53.060 --> 00:10:56.220
And, we went through those in that
episode about when you should and

210
00:10:56.220 --> 00:10:57.570
should not use those.

211
00:10:57.570 --> 00:11:01.480
So take that decision making that you
did previously, and apply it to here.

212
00:11:01.480 --> 00:11:04.760
For us, we have a small farm
in our lab environment.

213
00:11:04.760 --> 00:11:06.330
So we don't need a SQL server, so

214
00:11:06.330 --> 00:11:09.350
we're gonna just use

00:24:11.970 --> 00:24:16.590

459

00:24:48.925 --> 00:24:51.610

00:24:58.850 --> 00:25:02.748

you're actually gonna configure

474
00:25:25.820 --> 00:25:29.600

the set ADFS certificate authority and

475
00:25:29.600 --> 00:25:30.880
that exists today, but

476
00:25:30.880 --> 00:25:35.640

won't exist until you get that update.

477
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:39.340
Now the enrollment agent,
as you can think about that, that is, hey,

478
00:25:39.340 --> 00:25:43.050
what is the name of
the certificate template that

00:25:48.040 --> 00:25:50.460

00:25:50.460 --> 00:25:52.670
This is that internal name here.

00:25:52.670 --> 00:25:56.365

00:26:00.905 --> 00:26:05.335
certificate template that I'm going to

485
00:26:05.335 --> 00:26:08.377
And in here, I have my Windows Hello for
Business authentication,

486
00:26:08.377 --> 00:26:13.235
these are both those template
names that we created earlier.

487
00:26:13.235 --> 00:26:16.930
Now, an important thing here, again,
is, if you use different names,

488
00:26:16.930 --> 00:26:20.924
these things in green here, or these
parameters that are after the arguments,

489
00:26:20.924 --> 00:26:24.975
you're going to need to make sure to use
the appropriate names that you've had in

490
00:26:24.975 --> 00:26:26.740
for your environment.

491
00:26:26.740 --> 00:26:29.840
So what we're going to do is,
we have everything set,

492
00:26:29.840 --> 00:26:32.850
we're goinna go ahead and
hit enter on this.

493
00:26:32.850 --> 00:26:35.250
Okay, so as you can tell, it didn't work.

494
00:26:35.250 --> 00:26:39.880
And I spotted the error very quickly here,
so I've got the error.

495
00:26:39.880 --> 00:26:42.950
I know what I did wrong and
I forgot a very important command here.

496
00:26:42.950 --> 00:26:45.170
So what we're gonna do is I'll
paste in the right one here and

497
00:26:45.170 --> 00:26:46.620
we'll go through that.

498
00:26:46.620 --> 00:26:49.360
I did this enrollment agent,
you can see enrollment agent there.

499
00:26:49.360 --> 00:26:52.180
And then I pass the name of
the template to enrollment agent.

500
00:26:52.180 --> 00:26:53.800
So don't do that,

instead add the next command-let, which is

00:26:58.800 --> 00:27:01.790
That's where you wanna pass
the actual template to, and

503
00:27:01.790 --> 00:27:04.920
so then everything else stays
the same whereas the Windows Hello

00:27:04.920 --> 00:27:07.740
certificate template and
then you'll use that template.

505
00:27:07.740 --> 00:27:10.610
So, as they say,
one more time with feeling, we will

00:27:10.610 --> 00:27:15.050
try to run this command and in this

00:27:15.050 --> 00:27:19.380
go and let's see, I know I hit Enter.

508
00:27:19.380 --> 00:27:20.050
Maybe I didn't.

509
00:27:20.050 --> 00:27:21.030
Let's make sure I did.

510
00:27:22.240 --> 00:27:22.740
There we go.

511
00:27:23.760 --> 00:27:27.640
And so now, we have our command-let

512
00:27:27.640 --> 00:27:32.500
So what we can do is to see if

00:27:32.500 --> 00:27:36.400

515

So what I'm gonna do is I'm

00:27:52.420 --> 00:27:55.740
I don't think we're gonna have enough time

>> Yeah,
the validation's is real important, but

So, we'll gonna do a restart and

524
00:28:08.370 --> 00:28:11.655
And then in the next part, when we come

It's gonna take time and

00:28:34.211 --> 00:28:34.883
>> Perfect.
>> Awesome.
