>> Yep.
>> That's always good to avoid downtime

539
00:28:36.828 --> 00:28:38.174
and-
>> Absolutely.

00:28:38.174 --> 00:28:41.320
>> All right, ladies and gentlemen,

00:28:41.320 --> 00:28:44.150
Definitely tune back in for

So we definitely needed to do that and

00:28:49.260 --> 00:28:50.850

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike go through the steps required to verify the Registration Authority is properly configured and that certificate auto enrollment is properly issuing certificates to the ADFS service.

WEBVTT

1

3

7

We configured a bunch of things with

And we left off with stopping, or

14
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:32.200
with restarting our
Active Directory Federation Service.

15
00:00:32.200 --> 00:00:36.600
And so now we're gonna be going into
verifying that all the stuff we did,

16

And here to walk us through that process
Is Mr. Mike Stephens from Microsoft.

18
00:00:40.700 --> 00:00:41.910

19

>> Thanks for having me back Don.

20
00:00:42.920 --> 00:00:44.340
>> Not that you had much choice,

>> Everything, in theory,

>> Right, right,
we wanna take the theory part out.

But I mean, again I reiterated it

tools that you can use to go forward with.

34
00:01:21.830 --> 00:01:25.619
So the first thing we need to
do is we set up all the ADFS and

00:01:27.726 --> 00:01:29.852
Now if you remember back in that episode,

00:01:29.852 --> 00:01:34.458

And then that certificate is going to

00:01:43.480 --> 00:01:43.990
requests.

00:01:43.990 --> 00:01:49.281
But do we really know whether the ADFS
service really got the certificate or not?

00:01:49.281 --> 00:01:50.433
Because we did not do it manually.

44
00:01:50.433 --> 00:01:54.890
ADFS does all the certificate
management for us, which is great.

45
00:01:54.890 --> 00:01:57.320
Because, well we don't wanna
have to keep doing that work.

00:01:57.320 --> 00:02:01.310
So, in order to do that, we're gonna

00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:05.200
So, I'm gonna go to my ADFS server,

48
00:02:05.200 --> 00:02:08.031
And what we're going to do is
the first thing we're gonna do,

49
00:02:08.031 --> 00:02:10.816
is we're gonna open up these
application and service logs.

50
00:02:10.816 --> 00:02:14.670
And we're gonna go straight to the ADFS
logs and this administrative log.

51
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:18.780
Now we have a whole bunch of things in
here from when I was restarting and

52
00:02:18.780 --> 00:02:19.680
doing some other things.

53
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:23.540
But the key thing we wanna look in here
is this 443 event that's right here

54
00:02:23.540 --> 00:02:24.140
at the top.

55
00:02:24.140 --> 00:02:27.400
I'll bring that up so it's a little
bit more visible to everybody.

56
00:02:27.400 --> 00:02:29.690
And this 443 event tells us that,

57
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:34.340
hey, the CA enrollment certificate
management cycle was complete.

58
00:02:34.340 --> 00:02:37.960
As I said, the ADFS server does all
of the certificate management for us.

59
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:40.210
We don't need to enroll
certificates manually.

60
00:02:40.210 --> 00:02:43.410
We just tell it the template,
what template it needs to use, and boom,

61
00:02:43.410 --> 00:02:44.280
it goes.

62
00:02:44.280 --> 00:02:47.910
So we're like, okay, it's complete but
that still doesn't give us any

63
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:50.060
information of whether there's
a certificate there or not.

64
00:02:50.060 --> 00:02:53.530
So we have another event log that

65
00:02:53.530 --> 00:02:57.990
We used this event log earlier when we
were looking at the domain controller.

66
00:02:57.990 --> 00:03:02.360
But this one, ADFS service is
a group managed service account.

67
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:05.050
It's still an actual user account.

68
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:08.950
So what we need to do is we need to look
at the certificate life cycle log but

69
00:03:08.950 --> 00:03:12.110
we wanna do it for the user and
not the actual system.

70
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:17.310
So to do that, we're gonna expand

71
00:03:17.310 --> 00:03:19.790
And we're gonna scroll and

00:03:19.790 --> 00:03:22.730
you'll get to the Cs and

73
00:03:22.730 --> 00:03:23.690
Certificate service,

74
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:28.240
certificate right here, this is the guy

75
00:03:28.240 --> 00:03:31.830
And I'll spin this guy out so
you can see that this is the one for

76
00:03:31.830 --> 00:03:34.100
the system that we used earlier for
the domain control.

77
00:03:34.100 --> 00:03:37.436
But this is the one for
any user that's on this machine, and

78
00:03:37.436 --> 00:03:41.725
it's a really great log, cuz it tells
us when you enroll for a certificate.

79
00:03:41.725 --> 00:03:45.284
It will even tell you when a certificate
is deleted, which is really great for

80
00:03:45.284 --> 00:03:46.820
troubleshooting.

81
00:03:46.820 --> 00:03:47.985
So let's expand this log out.

82
00:03:47.985 --> 00:03:52.960
And you're going to look that it says,
hey a new certificate was installed.

83
00:03:52.960 --> 00:03:55.810
Okay, so let's look at that certificate.

84
00:03:55.810 --> 00:03:56.670
Let's see what it is.

85
00:03:58.110 --> 00:03:59.888
If we look in here and go, wow, hey.

86
00:03:59.888 --> 00:04:02.590
The MicrosoftIdentitServer
ServiceHost.exe.

87
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:04.430
Well little do you know that's ADFS.

88
00:04:04.430 --> 00:04:06.030
And if that wasn't a giveaway,

89
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:09.636
our account name gives us a really
good indicator that the ADFS service,

90
00:04:09.636 --> 00:04:13.820
that group managed service account is
actually the one enrolled for that.

91
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:17.660
And it's in the user's context and it
tells us the action was an enrollment so

92
00:04:17.660 --> 00:04:22.320
we know that the ADFS service, so
far Don, it's looking like it's working.

93
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:25.470
Let's keep going more,
we have a certificate thumbprint.

94
00:04:25.470 --> 00:04:29.050
This is gonna be really good so
let's remember these last four here.

95
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:32.140
This c17a,
this is gonna be important later.

96
00:04:33.530 --> 00:04:36.480
The great thing is is that
it has our template in here.

97
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:43.420
So now we know that this template was
actually, used our certificate template.

98
00:04:43.420 --> 00:04:47.770
And it tells us the name of the which
is that certificate registration

99
00:04:47.770 --> 00:04:48.550
request agent.

100
00:04:48.550 --> 00:04:51.170
>> So the nice part here Mike is
that by looking in the event log we

101
00:04:51.170 --> 00:04:51.760
see the events.

102
00:04:51.760 --> 00:04:53.860
We know that these

103
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:57.148
We don't have to take it for

104
00:04:57.148 --> 00:05:01.550
Cuz we can't log in as the ADFS
service account to see things.

105
00:05:01.550 --> 00:05:05.340
But here we're able to see it in the logs,

106
00:05:05.340 --> 00:05:07.010
And that helps with our troubleshooting,

107
00:05:07.010 --> 00:05:08.360
>> Yeah, I mean, absolutely, Don.

108
00:05:08.360 --> 00:05:10.290
We know that the event logs don't lie.

109
00:05:10.290 --> 00:05:12.130
We did enroll a cert.

110
00:05:12.130 --> 00:05:15.760
And there's enough data in the event

111
00:05:15.760 --> 00:05:17.660
that the ADFS service account enrolled for

112
00:05:17.660 --> 00:05:20.350
this cert has the rights

113
00:05:20.350 --> 00:05:22.055
All of these things are there.

114
00:05:22.055 --> 00:05:25.950
The thing about this is it really only
give us a high level information.

115
00:05:25.950 --> 00:05:28.780
If you recall back in when we
did the domain controller one,

116
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:32.430
we could actually open up the certificate
manager and look at that certificate.

117
00:05:32.430 --> 00:05:37.000
And see like the validity period and other
attributes like the subject name and this.

118
00:05:37.000 --> 00:05:39.950
We can't see that from the event log.

119
00:05:39.950 --> 00:05:43.630
So we really wanna make sure it's
like if you're having problems

120
00:05:43.630 --> 00:05:46.240
a certificate enrolled but
having a bad subject name or

121
00:05:46.240 --> 00:05:50.600
having it being expired,
we need to be able to see that.

122
00:05:50.600 --> 00:05:53.120
And this is where the problem lies.

123
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:57.180
You can't use the certificate manager

124
00:05:57.180 --> 00:05:58.040
it just doesn't work.

125
00:05:59.320 --> 00:06:02.270
The certificate manager was built
way before group managed services

126
00:06:02.270 --> 00:06:07.245

to be able to see that certificate.

127
00:06:08.380 --> 00:06:13.460
Luckily though, we can actually find
a way, and this is a really cool trick

128
00:06:13.460 --> 00:06:16.780
in being able to see certificates that

>> So in every other group we've made,

>> Yes, on this particular group,

And this is kind of gonna date or

00:17:29.430 --> 00:17:34.170
